title: Episode 151 – Nicolette Hahn Niman, Author, “Defending Beef” – Regenerative Grazing
subtitle: AboutDefending Beef
description: InDefending Beef(a Chelsea Green Publishing book), Nicolette details how our globed evolved over millions of years with very large herds of grazing animals playing a central role in Earth’s carbon cycles, water cycles, and atmospheric stability, and how that has been disrupted in recent millennia through human activity, especially industrialized mechanical and chemical agriculture. Buffaloe, bovines, caribou, wildebeest, cape buffalo, and other grazers moved through the landscape in vast, dense congregations. Now, through a form of agricultural biomimicry, humans can help restore balance by intensively grazing large herbivores, working in harmony with sunlight, rainfall, soil life, plants, and animals to sequester the anthropogenic carbon that we humans have released to the atmosphere in staggering amounts over the past three centuries, and especially since WWI and WWII. In tandem with substantial reduction in fossil fuel combustion, regenerative grazing is our most promising – and proven – strategy for climate change mitigation.

about_sections.about_what’s_so_special_cows?: With a potent ensemble of enzymes, microflora, and microfauna in their saliva and manure, cattle are literally walking, “mooing,” organic fertilizer dispensers. As biodynamic rancher Brook Le Van has described, Cattle tend to deposit twice the fertility that they consume when grazing in healthy pastures (see Brook’s and other related podcast episodes below). Additionally, as they selectively graze a mixture of grasses and herbaceous plants, cows naturally generate some of the most nutrient dense food available to humanity – with a unique blend of essential fatty acids, omega-3, and other brain-boosting, bone-strengthening, and immune-enhancing compounds difficult to obtain in sufficient quantities from other natural food sources. The intimate connection between our evolution and our consumption of grazing animals, according to Nicolette, is one of the most important threads running through the last 3,000,000 years of our species’ development – especially our brains and intelligence.
about_sections.about_nicolette_hahn_niman: Nicolette Hahn Nimanis a writer, attorney, and livestock rancher.  She authored the booksDefending Beef(2014, and 2d ed. 2021) andRighteous Porkchop(2009), as well as numerous essays for theNew York Times, The Wall Street Journal,andLos Angeles Times.  She has also written forThe Atlantic,The San Francisco Chronicle, andThe Earth Island Journal.  She is a frequent speaker at national and international conferences, and was one of just 23 speakers from around the world at the Nobel Week Dialogue 2016 in Stockholm, Sweden.  She has appeared onThe PBS Newshour,The Dr. Oz Showand in numerous films and documentaries, includingEating AnimalsandSustainable, and her work has been featured inTIME, O Magazine,andThe Guardian, among others.  Previously, she was Senior Attorney for the environmental organization Waterkeeper, where she focused on animal agriculture; before that, she was an environmental lawyer for National Wildlife Federation.  Hahn Niman served two terms on the City Commission for Kalamazoo, Michigan.  Today, she lives in Northern California with her two sons, and her husband, Bill Niman, founder of the natural meat companies Niman Ranch and BN Ranch.

full_transcript:
[10.9s - 26.4s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today, we're visiting with Nicolette Han Niamen, the author of Defending Beef. Nicolette, hey, how you doing? It's so great to see you today.

[26.4s - 29.4s]: Thank you. I'm so happy to be here with you.

[31.0s - 48.1s]: Nicolette Han Niamen is a writer, attorney, and livestock rancher. She authored the book Defending Beef as well as the book, Righteous Pork Chop, and has written numerous essays for the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, and the Los Angeles Times.

[48.1s - 54.9s]: She has also written for the Atlantic, the San Francisco Chronicle, and the Earth Island Journal.

[55.9s - 67.8s]: Nicolette is a frequent speaker at National and International conferences, and was one of just 23 speakers from around the world at the Nobel Week Dialogue in 2016 in Stockholm, Sweden.

[68.5s - 79.2s]: She has appeared on the PBS News Hour, the Dr. Oz Show, and in numerous films and documentaries, including eating animals, as well as sustainable.

[80.0s - 85.0s]: And her work has been featured in Time, O Magazine, and the Guardian, among many others.

[85.8s - 99.3s]: Previously, she was senior attorney for the Environmental Organization Waterkeeper, where she focused on animal agriculture, and before that was an Environmental Lawyer for National Wildlife Federation.

[101.2s - 114.8s]: Nicolette served two terms on the City Commission for Kalamazoo, Michigan, and today, she lives in Northern California, with her two sons and her husband, Bill Niamen, founder of the Natural Meat Companies, Niamen Ranch and BN Ranch.

[115.7s - 140.0s]: Nicolette, today, we're talking about defending beef, and I'm really, really excited to get into this topic, because among the many themes and threads out there in the climate movement, the regenerative movement, the food and health movement, this issue seems to be one that bubbles up quite often, and has a lot of misperceptions and varying views and opinions out there in the public.

[140.0s - 151.0s]: So maybe to kick things off, I'll just throw it right up for you. Maybe it's a bit of a softball. Why does beef need defending?

[152.5s - 165.6s]: Yes, well, I kind of wish that it didn't, because it's a kind of a frustrating process to have to try to defend something over and over again that you kind of don't feel needs to be defended.

[166.6s - 184.6s]: But I guess it's kind of a two-pronged response. On the one hand, there's this whole question of the healthfulness of the food. Is it something that is good for our bodies and will sustain our health over the longer term?

[185.6s - 198.6s]: And that's an idea that's kind of been out there. I would say since around mid-20th century, there was this kind of rise in heart disease in the industrialized world.

[198.6s - 209.6s]: And there were actually two major camps on the topic. One really felt that it related to the consumption of animal fats in the industrialized world.

[209.9s - 228.3s]: And then there was another group of researchers, scientists and physicians that felt that actually the shift towards more sugar in the industrialized diet was much more important in terms of what might be triggering the rise in heart disease and other diet related diseases.

[229.7s - 236.4s]: And unfortunately, the sort of the dietary fat argument kind of won the day at the time.

[237.0s - 251.3s]: And even though over the last couple of decades, there has been some really good and credible re-evaluation of the thought process and the research to the point where I would say the argument has actually been dismantled.

[252.0s - 262.4s]: But it was out there for so many decades that it's still a very mainstream belief, even among nutritionists, dieticians and doctors.

[262.8s - 269.6s]: But from my perspective, the science is basically has been broken down to the point where it's not credible anymore.

[270.3s - 276.9s]: So on the health side, there's still this argument that we shouldn't be eating it because of primarily because of the saturated fat content.

[276.9s - 286.7s]: And the other side, and this is kind of a more, is a little bit newer of an argument, there's this argument that meat is too ecologically damaging.

[286.7s - 295.1s]: It's too resource intensive, it's too water intensive, and it's specifically beef. The beef is the one that usually gets the focus in this arena.

[295.8s - 302.8s]: And then in the last decade, in particular, this idea that it's too harmful to the climate, especially because of methane.

[303.8s - 326.1s]: So as a person who was kind of a lifelong environmentalist and spent three years specifically working as a lawyer for environmental organizations, nonprofit organizations, and two of those years were specifically focused on the meat industry, I'm someone who really has kind of delved into this from on a professional level.

[327.0s - 342.3s]: This, you know, what what does the science really say on the ecology? And then for the last 20 years, I've been living and working on a ranch and I have met ranchers all over the world and really studied it from that perspective, from a practitioner's perspective.

[342.3s - 352.4s]: And so I have increasingly become convinced that the ecological argument is just just very, very wrong on many levels.

[352.7s - 372.0s]: And so what my defense of beef is is kind of this too, too pronged, you know, reputation of these two sort of, you know, I'd say almost commonly held beliefs that that beef is not good for your health and that beef is damaging to the environment.

[372.3s - 387.6s]: And so I, you know, the more the more I learned about it, the more I felt that someone who had a kind of a not just a deep understanding, but a kind of a nuance understanding because of these various different components to my background.

[387.6s - 402.5s]: And someone needed to really make a cohesive argument that beef was valuable food for our health and also ecologically when done well beneficial.

[403.4s - 404.0s]: Yeah.

[405.2s - 414.6s]: You know, I'm really, really excited. We have the opportunity to dive into this with you and unpack this a little bit for our audience.

[415.6s - 429.4s]: And I have found, you know, in the years I've been doing this kind of related work that this this beef and animal issues seems to be among the most polarizing out there.

[429.4s - 459.4s]: At least in the portion of our national demographic that finds the anthropomorphic climate change concerned to be genuine and what's amazing to me and what many Americans aren't aware of is that globally virtually everybody seems to be in an agreement and understanding that human impacted climate change.

[459.4s - 463.9s]: And so, you know, I think that this is very real, even though here in the United States, there seems to be some confusion about this.

[464.5s - 486.7s]: But within the arena of folks who are taking that threat seriously, this seems to be one of the most polarizing divisive issues, which is astonishing for those of us who are engaged directly in agriculture and especially regenerative agriculture.

[486.7s - 508.7s]: And, you know, we collaborate with dozens and dozens of farmers and ranchers at many scales and not one yet in all of these years have I come across a farmer of rancher who says, yeah, we can maintain and steward soil and landscapes and ecosystems and food production without animals.

[509.6s - 513.3s]: And particularly the bovine, and animals.

[514.9s - 531.7s]: So, I'm hoping and in your book is so well documented, I'm going to show it to our audience that are looking at the video version of this here. And of course, audio, you're not seeing this, but it's such a beautiful book published by our friends at Chelsea Green Publishing.

[531.7s - 550.2s]: And the book is so well documented. And I'm hoping that you can paint a picture for us of the scene, if you will, of cattle grazing on grasslands, the soil ecology, the water, the wildlife, the biodiversity.

[550.2s - 558.5s]: Because I think a lot of folks have a very different picture in mind when thinking about this issue.

[559.5s - 576.3s]: Well, first of all, you said so much, and I just want to respond quickly to a couple of points you made. First of all, I have traveled around the world quite a bit in various contexts and talking a lot of times and talking about beef and and and other, you know, capacities where I'm traveling.

[576.3s - 588.1s]: And I'm always really struck by how the farming and ranching community in other parts of the world is not arguing that climate change is not happening.

[588.3s - 600.1s]: So, it's still a uniquely American phenomenon pretty much that that is still a pretty widely held view in certain quarters of the agricultural community.

[600.1s - 606.8s]: Although I do think that's shifting. I have noticed a dramatic difference from five or 10 years ago that there's more and more acceptance of it.

[607.1s - 620.2s]: And also, interest in the idea of, okay, what can agriculture do? How can we be proactively preparing for these changes? And also, how can we be making our own practices better so that we're not contributing to the problem?

[620.2s - 649.6s]: So, I think that's kind of how I see where that situation is. And then with respect to this whole question of the role of animals, I mean, I, you know, I was explaining this issue and thinking about it and writing about it for a long time before I ever heard something that Alan Savory said, the wildlife ecologist from Zimbabwe, who has done such an amazing job.

[650.2s - 661.1s]: He's been managing sort of holistic management principles in grazing and agriculture in many parts of the world. And the way he said it that just made some so much sense to me.

[661.1s - 672.5s]: And I think it's such a beautiful sort of encapsulation of the whole book that I wrote defending beef. And that is that essentially the globe evolved for millions of years.

[673.8s - 688.7s]: And for those, for millions and millions of years, there were very large herds of grazing animals. And that that was a very important element of the Earth's ecology.

[689.3s - 699.4s]: And that only in fairly recent times, you know, so like about the last 100,000 years, which is a long time. But it's very short in geological time.

[700.4s - 723.0s]: Many of those animals either disappeared entirely or their populations dwindled dramatically. So we have today, just kind of a remnant of the wild grazing herds, whether they were, you know, prehistoric animals or things like caribou, which are still on the Earth, but are in much smaller numbers now.

[723.9s - 735.5s]: And you can just look at it when I give talks and I, you know, show slides of the sort of the remem remnants of large grazing herds that are still on the Earth.

[735.9s - 747.2s]: Caribou being one of them. And we also have things like Kate Buffalo and Will de Beast and the bison in the American West, although they're a tiny fraction of what they want to work.

[747.2s - 765.8s]: But what I, what I like about showing them to people, the visualization is so important. You can see that there are large number of numbers of animals. And they're very densely congregated as they move across the landscape and they do move.

[766.4s - 779.5s]: And so what what Alan Savory said a few years ago, and I've met him many times and I, I have a strong connection with them and have read his, you know, seminal book about holistic management.

[780.6s - 791.5s]: But he, he said in these words that just clicked in my mind is that we need a proxy, a replacement for the disappeared wild animals that once covered the glow.

[791.5s - 804.8s]: And so that is why he and I also strongly believe in this idea that the grazing animals like cattle in particular are not just, you know, OK.

[806.1s - 814.9s]: They're essential for the ecological function of the Earth. And you can, you know, kind of break it down into a lot of different components of why that is.

[814.9s - 827.4s]: But I think just thinking of it in that context is really helpful. If you think, you know, for, for the vast majority of, you know, for millions and millions of years, there were tens of millions of years.

[827.8s - 842.1s]: There were large grazing herds and they're largely absent today. So we need to sort of figure out how to have that same kind of ecological impact on the Earth in order for ecosystems to function properly.

[842.1s - 856.6s]: And especially for the soil to function properly. And so that is kind of a cornerstone of the defending beef book. And I have to say when I first started researching and writing the book, the original version of it.

[857.2s - 872.1s]: I didn't even know what I just said. Like I had a lot of other reasons that I thought I could make a great argument for cattle. But this whole idea that they are absolutely essential for soil biology and the environment.

[872.1s - 889.5s]: And then I got into the question of the sort of microbiology. And then it goes way back to this long sort of geological perspective of Earth's long existence was something I did not understand until, you know, much more recently, and when I started writing this book, that's kind of this short version of the argument.

[890.9s - 914.9s]: Yeah, it's so important. And I want to pick up on that and add a little to it. When we were researching for my book, Why on Earth and our soil, Stewards of Handbook, we were looking at the numbers globally for carbon concentration in the atmosphere in the form of carbon dioxide and methane and some other compounds.

[914.9s - 944.8s]: And carbon in the living canopies of the forests, et cetera, carbon in the living soils worldwide. And looking at those aggregate numbers, we essentially saw that a 10% increase in soil carbon worldwide from the natural sequestering of atmospheric carbon would be tantamount to sequestering of carbon dioxide.

[944.8s - 963.6s]: Virtually all of the industrial and fossil carbon that we've released since the beginning of the industrial revolution. And so there's this very important nexus in the soil itself, right, vis-a-vis the climate and carbon cycling.

[963.6s - 976.6s]: I was hoping you could unpack that for us a little bit as well and help us understand, you know, what's going on with the large grazing animals vis-a-vis that kind of carbon soil climate atmosphere connection.

[977.4s - 988.6s]: Yeah, well, I think a couple of important kind of foundational points on that one is that there's been this very large migration of carbon into the atmosphere.

[988.6s - 995.7s]: And that a lot of that has come from the soil and that has been well documented that there's been a dramatic loss.

[997.2s - 1004.6s]: Basically starting around, you know, the mid 1800s when this sort of industrialization process really started happening.

[1005.1s - 1015.4s]: But we've had, you know, we have kind of a long human history that has been impacting the life and health of the soil. And a lot of that relates to the plow.

[1015.4s - 1028.6s]: You know, and I was very surprised when I was, you know, again, sort of in my research, I was uncovering, you know, West Jackson saying things like nothing has done more damage to the earth than the plow.

[1029.8s - 1037.5s]: And it's something that most people, again, especially people outside of agricultural circles would never have thought of that. I don't think.

[1037.5s - 1045.2s]: But it's just this basic idea that the earth itself has kind of a protective vegetative blanket.

[1046.2s - 1066.7s]: And whenever you sort of, whenever you run a plow through it or anything, it's kind of ripping it apart, you're not just taking that protective vegetative blanket off, but you're ripping all of the very complex networks, network of roots and filaments that are below ground.

[1066.7s - 1093.1s]: And you're doing tremendous damage to the whole sort of subterranean ecosystem that's down there that is, you know, I think just in the last decade, there's been a great deal more awareness of how complex that below ground environment is and how the microorganisms and all the living entities that are down there, whether there's been a lot of attention to earthworms and they're very important, but there's much more to it than that.

[1093.1s - 1108.1s]: And so whenever we plow the ground, we're sort of dramatically injuring the health of that whole system. And we've been doing this for thousands of years, not just since the 1850s.

[1108.8s - 1121.3s]: But so there's that's kind of collective impact of agriculture and other human activity that we've been having on how much life and health and carbon are in the soil, those things are all kind of connected.

[1122.3s - 1129.9s]: And then we have this sort of rapid acceleration of that whole process happening since the industrialization, the sort of industrial revolution.

[1131.6s - 1153.8s]: And so that's kind of a big piece of it. There's been this migration from basically from the soil to that atmosphere. And so when you talk about sort of trying to come up with ways to get more carbon back into the soil, not just to take it out of the atmosphere, but also to improve the health of the soil.

[1153.8s - 1166.5s]: And then something that I've become much more focused on and interested in the last couple of years in particular is just this whole question of the importance of doing that in order to create more healthful food.

[1167.2s - 1175.8s]: Like these whole, you know, these are sort of simple concepts in a way, but in another way, we rarely hear these things being discussed in the same conversation.

[1175.8s - 1195.9s]: And I've gotten very intrigued by work of people like Fred Provenza, who've shown how when you have soil that isn't helpful enough, you know, it impacts, you know, what it's not biologically vibrant enough, it impacts the health of the plant that's growing there.

[1195.9s - 1218.6s]: And then even that affects the health of the animal that's grazing it. And then, of course, there's a lot of research now showing that modern versions of fruits, vegetables, grains, even animal foods that were consuming have a much lower nutrient content that content, they have lower nutritional value to humans.

[1218.6s - 1240.0s]: And a lot of that is being connected to this lack of life and health in the soil. So all of this stuff is connected. And the reason why Erin, you asked me about the role of animals in that. So animals by being there, you know, and they were there for millions of years having this impact, these wild grazing animals.

[1240.1s - 1246.1s]: And then of course, domesticated, right grazing animals have been around for quite a while as well, but in the thousands of years, not in the millions of years.

[1246.1s - 1275.4s]: But where an animal treads, it has a number of impacts just by virtue of, you know, for example, pushing seeds into the ground, where it grazes it clips vegetation, which fosters growth, and also allows other species of plants that are later sprouting to come up because they have more sunshine that are actually reaching them as seedlings.

[1276.3s - 1284.1s]: So there's research from all around the world showing that there's greater diversity of vegetation where you have grazing animals, whether domesticated or wild.

[1285.1s - 1295.8s]: And then of course, there's the impact of the manure on the sort of not just people talk a lot of times about the fact that manure has nitrogen, phosphorus, et cetera, in it.

[1295.8s - 1321.9s]: But even more importantly, perhaps is the fact that manure has a lot of microorganisms in it. And so between the nutrients, the moisture, and the microorganisms manure actually has a dramatically positive effect on the healthfulness of the soil, how much life is in there, and ultimately how much water is retained in there, which allows more life to exist in the soil.

[1322.4s - 1341.2s]: And so the grazing animal, if you don't manage it, you know, again, to sort of go back to the Ellen savory concept of proxy for a wild animal, if you manage it in a, in a, in a sort of thoughtful way, usually one that kind of mimics the disappeared wild animal that might have been there.

[1342.2s - 1352.3s]: You will have tremendously beneficial effects from the presence of that animal. It needs to be kind of moving. It needs to be the land needs to be resting.

[1353.1s - 1365.0s]: But the fact that there's that grazing, the cropping of the vegetation, the addition of the manure, and the urine back into the soil and the addition of the microorganisms that are.

[1365.0s - 1395.0s]: And also even just recently I was reading something about saliva and the saliva of the animal having an impact on the growth of the plants. So there are just many, many levels, some of which are still being figured out, where it has a positive effect on how much vegetation you have, how much diversity of vegetation, and not just the diversity of the vegetation, but everything from the diversity of microorganisms, the diversity of the insect life, all of these things have been shared.

[1395.0s - 1415.5s]: And so I've shown in many, many studies from around the world to be, to be more vibrant, more abundant, just more diverse, where you have the grazing animals. And they've actually done quite a few studies in every, every place from Europe, Asia, United States, where animals were removed from a plot of land.

[1415.5s - 1432.4s]: And a lot of times it's like a park or something like that. And there's a belief that this will help kind of help the land to recover. And there's been a sort of surprising result over and over again to the point where it's not even surprising anymore, you know, that the health of the ecosystem declines.

[1432.4s - 1447.8s]: And that's something that Alan Sabry talks about as well, that in his work as a wildlife ecologist, that a lot of the work that he was doing when he was younger, they were trying to reduce numbers of grazing animals, whether they were wild or domesticated.

[1447.8s - 1473.6s]: And that again and again, he was witnessing for himself in the African landscapes that the health of the whole ecosystem was declining when they would remove these animals. And that's what kind of triggered his whole life's work of trying to figure out how do we use grazing animals as an ecological renovator and protector rather than, you know, viewing them as inherently damaging.

[1476.2s - 1482.0s]: Yeah, and I think, you know, for a lot of people, that is a major paradigm shift right there.

[1482.1s - 1482.2s]: Right.

[1484.1s - 1497.6s]: I was struck, you know, we've had our friend, my friend, Brookle of Van, a co founder of sustainable settings, a beautiful biodynamic ranch here in Colorado, did a multi year study with the NRCS.

[1497.6s - 1507.3s]: And this study included a number of different farms and ranches ranging from conventional to organic and biodynamic practices.

[1507.9s - 1520.5s]: And in the case of sustainable settings, combination of biodynamic regenerative practices and rotational grazing and some of the methods recommended by Alan Sabry and others.

[1520.5s - 1542.1s]: The soil carbon levels grew so dramatically that they literally after a handful of years went off the charts, like literally had to change the vertical axis increments, the NRCS did to accommodate the results they were seeing at sustainable settings.

[1542.1s - 1555.1s]: And so we hear whether it's through the Sabry Institute's work or the ecosystem restoration camp movement worldwide and they rebranded as ecosystem restoration communities.

[1555.1s - 1580.2s]: We're seeing in places all around the world, including full blown deserts, this ability to restore landscapes ecosystems and thereby sequester incredible amounts of carbon, well also significantly impacting the hydrology, the water flows in those regions.

[1580.2s - 1605.4s]: And I know one of the chapters in your book is dedicated to the water. And I was hoping you could you could unpack that a bit for us as well, because I think there's all we see some of the old studies that have probably been debunked by now indicating, oh, you know, to raise one beef cow cow or steer you need so many hundreds of gallons of water.

[1605.4s - 1611.7s]: But this is creating a significant misperception about what that actually really means in the landscape, right?

[1612.3s - 1619.1s]: Yes. And first of all, I just want to pause and say I love the way you, I don't know if it's intentional or not, the way you said, restore.

[1619.1s - 1635.7s]: Because I had never thought about that word that way. It is, it is, it is about getting back in, storing again, something that once was there, the carbon and the water and the life into the soil and into the landscape.

[1635.7s - 1653.0s]: So, yes, water is something that I've focused on a lot over the years as an environmental lawyer, actually both the job I did at National Wildlife Federation, as well as the job I did at waterkeeper were focused a lot almost primarily on water.

[1653.6s - 1657.8s]: So, it's something I've worked on and thought about a lot and read a lot about.

[1658.9s - 1682.1s]: And I think it is one of the biggest misperceptions around beef specifically because there have been these kind of, you know, they were, they were around long before memes existed, you know, but there were these things flying around saying that, you know, your hamburger was, you know, a lakes worth of water, you know, whatever, ridiculous exaggeration.

[1682.1s - 1695.9s]: And I, again, when I sort of actually looked at the research and looked at the studies and understood what the numbers meant, I was really surprised at how false that argument is because for many different reasons.

[1695.9s - 1725.0s]: And I kind of break it down in some detail in the, in my book, defending beef, but this, you know, again, kind of the short version is that for one thing, the vast, vast, vast majority of water that goes into beef anywhere in the world, but certainly here in the United States is from rainfall is, it's not water that's being extracted from the ground, it's not water that's being, you know, taken from a lake or from municipal water system or whatever.

[1725.0s - 1746.6s]: It's rainfall, okay, so it's water that would be there anyways and then the question is, well, what happens with it and the really interesting part that I think really surprises people is that that water gets, you know, sort of captured in the soil and it ends up being stored essentially in vegetation.

[1746.6s - 1758.1s]: And as we've been talking about vegetation has a really valuable role in protecting the soil, protecting the below ground environment, protecting the whole ecosystem.

[1759.2s - 1775.6s]: And actually that whole grass system or, you know, whatever vegetative system you're talking about really benefits by this, this animal impact, you sort of have to have the grazing of it in order for it to be diverse and for the growth to be triggered.

[1775.6s - 1790.4s]: And so forth and grazing animals do that, but it's that water in the vegetation that makes up the vast majority of the water that's in those water footprint numbers.

[1790.4s - 1811.4s]: So from my perspective, that water really doesn't even belong in that number and the these a group of scientists, a number of years ago at UC Davis also felt that way and made that argument and they did a detailed analysis of how much water would go into a pound of beef.

[1811.8s - 1818.5s]: If you didn't count that number, if you didn't count the water that's in the grass, essentially, and the natural rainfall that's in the grass, okay.

[1818.5s - 1832.9s]: And what they found was that the number that water that beef is still, you know, more water intensive than some other foods that's undeniable, but it was actually comparable to other foods that people commonly eat such as rice.

[1833.9s - 1845.8s]: And so it to it dramatically reduced it doesn't it's not an outsized water footprint. It's a water footprint that's, you know, comparable to many other things that people already eat.

[1845.8s - 1853.6s]: And so I think that's just to me that's like it's kind of a context point, you know, you need to think of it in the greater context.

[3502.1s - 3508.6s]: mostly urban and suburban environments, we're kind of missing out on this opportunity to get exposure

[3508.6s - 3514.8s]: to all kinds of, you know, microorganisms in our environments from soil, from animals, from plants.

[3515.5s - 3524.9s]: And it's, you know, everything from perhaps pandemics, like the COVID pandemic that we obviously

[3524.9s - 3530.5s]: all just recently experienced, we're just more vulnerable as a population now to lots of different

[3530.5s - 3536.3s]: kinds of problems, whether they're infectious diseases or allergies or things like asthma. And

[3536.3s - 3542.5s]: you know, that may sound kind of hoki to someone who hasn't been hearing about this. But there's

[3542.5s - 3549.7s]: really quite a lot of science on this now. And ironically, you know, again, kind of not the cow,

[3550.0s - 3558.4s]: it's the how where you have large concentrated forms of animal agriculture, it can have a negative

[3558.4s - 3564.0s]: effect. Lots, lots of different kinds of negative effects on human health. But also there hasn't really

[3564.0s - 3571.7s]: been nearly as much showing of a positive impact on immunity for people living in those environments

[3571.7s - 3576.4s]: because you're actually, you know, first of all, the kinds of exposure that you're going to get are

[3576.4s - 3585.6s]: different. And you don't have that sort of daily interaction with healthy animals that are going

[3585.6s - 3592.6s]: to help your body develop immunity and just ability to cope with all different kinds of microorganisms

[3592.6s - 3599.4s]: that you get when you are on a more diversified farm that has a regular interaction with healthy animals.

[3599.4s - 3605.0s]: So yeah, it's a super interesting topic that I think there's a lot of research going on. The

[3605.0s - 3609.4s]: research I cite in the book comes from various parts of the world in Europe and the United States and

[3609.4s - 3616.2s]: elsewhere. But I think interestingly, just on PBS, just like a couple of years ago, I saw

[3616.2s - 3620.8s]: something about asthma and they were talking about it and they said, if you can possibly be around

[3620.8s - 3626.2s]: animals of any kind, that's good. And I thought, oh, that's interesting because I swear, you know,

[3626.2s - 3631.9s]: 20 years ago, they would have been saying, if you have asthma, avoid animals, but I think, you know,

[3632.0s - 3639.2s]: there's a growing understanding of the importance of exposing yourself to things in order to be

[3639.2s - 3643.9s]: healthier. And even with food allergies, they're starting to use exposure therapy more. So,

[3645.9s - 3651.4s]: yeah, I don't know if I said that. Yeah, it's you were helping, I thought about it or not.

[3651.4s - 3658.2s]: Yeah, no, it's perfect. And really the emphasis on healthy animals, right? So when we're talking

[3658.2s - 3663.3s]: about these issues, what we're not talking about just to be crystal clear, are the concentrated

[3663.3s - 3669.8s]: animal feeding units otherwise known as feed lots where conditions are very different than

[3670.7s - 3681.4s]: naturally grazing animals out on pasture, right? It's a very different type of system. And when

[3682.1s - 3690.7s]: eating diverse nutrient-dense foods, and for us humans, this is also critical, and you point out

[3690.7s - 3702.2s]: that with grass fed past your ranged beef, we are getting a whole suite of very important nutrition

[3703.1s - 3711.8s]: that often isn't available through sort of vegetarian process food alternatives,

[3712.6s - 3718.7s]: or other foods that we might be eating these days, especially in the modern industrial context.

[3719.2s - 3725.1s]: And I was hoping that you could walk us through what's going on, and why are these nutrients,

[3725.5s - 3731.4s]: particularly bioavailable as you point out? And how is this impacting bones, muscles, brains,

[3733.0s - 3737.1s]: the good functioning of mind-body spirit, if you will, for each of us as humans?

[3738.3s - 3745.2s]: Yeah, well, I get, my background is as a biologist. That was my major in undergrad, and I also

[3745.2s - 3752.8s]: have this very long history as a child, and growing up with my parents, who were very focused on

[3753.3s - 3759.8s]: sort of being out in nature and eating good food and getting lots of exercise. And so I had this

[3759.8s - 3764.7s]: kind of focus on health, and how do you live healthfully that goes back since literally birth.

[3767.0s - 3773.1s]: And one of the things that has always just sort of inherently made sense to me is, again, to sort of

[3773.1s - 3778.7s]: think about our evolution as a species, and what we're doing, and what have we always done,

[3778.9s - 3786.4s]: and therefore our physiology is constructed in such a way that expects to get certain things.

[3787.2s - 3793.9s]: And I think it's very important to note that we began eating as a species, we began, and

[3793.9s - 3799.9s]: sort of, again, our pre-human ancestors, began eating meat over three million years ago.

[3800.4s - 3811.9s]: So that's a lot of time during which we as a species were evolving with that being a key component

[3811.9s - 3817.3s]: of our diet, and there's all kinds of arguments about how much and how necessary and blah blah blah.

[3817.8s - 3823.9s]: But there's no doubt whatsoever that we've been eating meat for a very, very long time, and that

[3823.9s - 3833.4s]: it was a key component of our evolution. There's so much nourishment in meat that it helped us to

[3833.4s - 3839.0s]: grow bigger grains, but it was also the complexity of hunting, which is said to have contributed to the

[3839.0s - 3844.5s]: fact that we evolved bigger grains, and we just evolved sort of more complex inter, you know,

[3844.6s - 3850.0s]: societies, more complex communities, and relationships with one another in order to be able to

[3850.0s - 3857.0s]: hunt and to be able to prepare the meat. And meat has been one of these foods that for a very,

[3857.0s - 3862.0s]: very long time has been cooked. In fact, I don't know if you've read that book by Richard Rangham

[3862.0s - 3866.6s]: Catching Fire, which I love, and I had the pleasure of spending time with him when I was at the Nobel

[3866.6s - 3874.5s]: event, actually. And his whole argument is that we actually were cooking, that cooking has been

[3874.5s - 3880.4s]: a really important part of our evolution, and that maybe one of the reasons why some of the pathogens

[3880.4s - 3886.4s]: that are more concerning are from meat in our food system is because of the fact that we never

[3886.4s - 3892.7s]: really evolved to eat meat raw. It's one of the foods that we, for a very, very long time,

[3892.7s - 3901.4s]: have been cooking. And so we, he argues, haven't really evolved the sort of systems to counter the

[3901.4s - 3908.7s]: pathogens that occur in meat. So there's no debate whatsoever that it's been an essential

[3908.7s - 3914.4s]: part of our evolution for a variety of different reasons. And again, if you sort of think of it from

[3914.4s - 3922.0s]: that perspective, I think it's easy to understand that our physiology is built to kind of expect

[3922.6s - 3928.5s]: those nutrients to come to us. And a lot of other foods that have, for example, protein, protein

[3928.5s - 3935.4s]: is a food that, um, a macro nutrient that we get a lot of from meat, fish, dairy, eggs.

[3936.2s - 3943.3s]: And then, of course, there are plant sources to it as well. But what people very often fail to

[3943.3s - 3950.1s]: understand is that difference in bioavailability. Like how well can your body actually utilize it?

[3950.6s - 3954.7s]: And so when you look at a nutritional label for a food and it says it has

[3955.3s - 3959.9s]: five grams of protein in it or whatever, that doesn't mean your body's going to be able to

[3959.9s - 3967.9s]: utilize five grams. And the studies have been done. And again, kind of, you know, objective sources

[3967.9s - 3973.8s]: like the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization. They have huge divisions that study

[3973.8s - 3979.9s]: nutrition and health and diet. And they just emphasize over and over again in their documents

[3980.7s - 3987.5s]: that there's almost no way to replace the foods that come from animals, whether it's eggs, meat,

[3987.8s - 3996.5s]: fish, because they are so high in protein and many other nutrients. But also because the form

[3996.5s - 4001.4s]: that they come in is of such high quality. And in fact, there's a whole thing called a protein

[4001.4s - 4007.0s]: quality index. And so a lot of people think just by eating soy or just by eating, you know, potatoes,

[4007.3s - 4012.1s]: again, you're going to get enough protein. And in fact, there's a whole, which I think is a kind

[4012.1s - 4017.0s]: of an absurd, but there's a whole narrative out there that we eat too much protein in the

[4017.0s - 4023.4s]: industrialized world. I think actually that that that that is totally untrue. But in any case,

[4023.4s - 4029.8s]: we won't get bogged down in that point. But regardless, you won't get the the same quality

[4029.8s - 4035.6s]: protein from non animal-based foods. So for me, it kind of goes back to that evolutionary argument.

[4036.1s - 4044.5s]: And then there's sort of what I would call kind of an emerging body of science that's showing that

[4045.6s - 4053.5s]: the way food is raised impacts what's available nutritionally and that there are actually thousands

[4053.5s - 4058.5s]: of compounds contained in food that are not on a nutritional level at all. They're just sort of

[4058.5s - 4064.7s]: beginning to be identified. These phytochemicals, and they're not just available in plants,

[4065.3s - 4070.0s]: you know, vegetables and fruits, but they're also available in animal-based foods, meat,

[4070.0s - 4076.1s]: milk, and eggs. And how much of those chemicals, those naturally occurring chemicals,

[4076.7s - 4084.9s]: are present, depends on the way the animal was raised. So having an animal in a healthful environment,

[4084.9s - 4092.6s]: and as Fred Provenza shows in his study in his books, a diverse environment where they can

[4092.6s - 4099.7s]: graze on a lot of different kinds of plants is really important to producing food that is

[4101.3s - 4107.4s]: supportive of vibrant health over the long term. So you can substitute, you know, you can get

[4108.2s - 4112.0s]: something that contains calcium, you can get something that contains protein, blah, blah, blah,

[4112.0s - 4117.9s]: on a nutritional label. You can do that quite easily. You can construct a diet that would appear to

[4117.9s - 4124.6s]: meet your nutritional needs. I am more and more convinced that if you are eating foods that are from

[4124.6s - 4129.3s]: an industrial system, especially processed foods, I'm reading a whole book right now about

[4129.3s - 4136.2s]: ultra-processed foods called ultra-processed people by a British doctor and excellent book that I

[4136.2s - 4142.9s]: recommend to people. Anyone who's interested in this topic, it's basically making the argument that

[4142.9s - 4149.7s]: the core of what's wrong with sort of health in the industrialized world is how much processed

[4149.7s - 4157.1s]: food is being consumed. And so much of what people are eating when they stop eating meats or stop

[4157.1s - 4166.1s]: drinking milk or stop eating eggs is ultra-processed food. So to me, that is sort of at the crux of

[4166.1s - 4171.9s]: the danger of it. You're stopping eating something that we evolved with for millions of years,

[4171.9s - 4178.3s]: our physiology is built on reliance on it. And then you're substituting it with something that

[4178.3s - 4183.5s]: you're basically making yourself into a science experiment. What are the long-term health effects of

[4183.5s - 4189.5s]: these foods that have just been invented in the last decade or so? And I for one, I'm not willing

[4189.5s - 4195.1s]: to subject myself to that science experiment nor am I willing to subject my kids to that. So I try

[4195.7s - 4203.2s]: very, very hard to get as much food as possible from places that I know was well raised, it was local.

[4204.5s - 4208.6s]: The vast majority of the meat that we eat is meat that we raise ourselves. Not everybody obviously

[4208.6s - 4213.7s]: has that option, but they can get it from good sources. It's available all over the country.

[4214.5s - 4222.0s]: And to try to make as much food as possible ourselves and have, you know, as little processed

[4222.0s - 4225.5s]: food as possible, you're probably not going to ever totally get it out of your diet, but

[4226.1s - 4229.3s]: I'm working on it every day trying to minimize it.

[4230.5s - 4237.8s]: I love it. Niklai, it is so wonderful to have you walk us through these issues in such a

[4237.8s - 4246.7s]: clear, cogent, compelling manner. So grateful we could have the time today for you to join us on the

[4246.7s - 4255.8s]: podcast. And before signing off to do our behind the scenes segment, I want to invite you to do

[4255.8s - 4261.8s]: two things. And the first is if you're going to ask you this question, if you could

[4262.8s - 4272.2s]: wave your magic wand and help us envision what a fully regenerative food system looks like,

[4272.9s - 4279.4s]: and help us picture that and also help us understand the steps we can take to get there.

[4280.8s - 4288.2s]: I'd love for you to share that with us. Okay. So the first thing I would do, and this may sound

[4288.2s - 4294.6s]: like it's not related to regenerative agriculture, but I think it is, is my magic wand wave would give

[4294.6s - 4303.8s]: everyone on the planet the capacity to cook. Because again, the more I've learned and thought about

[4303.8s - 4309.8s]: this and read and talk to people over the years, the more convinced I am that when you are cooking,

[4309.8s - 4314.3s]: when you're gathering your own ingredients and preparing your own food and feeding people and

[4314.3s - 4320.1s]: feeding yourself with that food, you start to think about and you learn and you care about where

[4320.1s - 4325.5s]: it comes from, how it was produced, and you're going to be eating healthier food and you're going to

[4325.5s - 4332.9s]: be supporting a healthier food system. So that would be the first thing. The second thing is I would

[4333.6s - 4341.7s]: just get rid of all the big concentrated animal production facilities around the world because I

[4341.7s - 4349.3s]: think that those places do not produce healthy food. They do not, they have tremendous environmental

[4349.3s - 4355.0s]: impacts and impacts for the neighbors and the people working there and they do not create

[4355.6s - 4361.2s]: humane environments for the animals that live there. So I just really believe that as a human race,

[4361.3s - 4367.4s]: we should not be raising food that way. And then what I would want to do is take those animals

[4367.4s - 4375.6s]: and return them to the landscape around the world. Every farm would have lots of different things

[4375.6s - 4381.4s]: that it was doing. And actually, just a few months ago, I added to my presentations that I give.

[4381.7s - 4388.2s]: I added a slide from a grandma Moses painting and it was just as beautiful, I don't know if you've

[4388.2s - 4393.6s]: seen it before, Erin, but it's just as beautiful painting of a farm with all different kinds of

[4393.6s - 4397.9s]: things happening on it. Lots of different people interacting with each other in different ways

[4397.9s - 4405.0s]: and lots of different animals and plant crops and you just see how a farm in a traditional setting

[4405.6s - 4411.3s]: is a community and it's a place where there is community and where people are interacting with each

[4411.3s - 4416.9s]: other and with their animals and with their land and how there's just connectedness happening

[4416.9s - 4425.2s]: naturally. And so to me, the return of the animals of landscape and to more complex, more diverse

[4425.2s - 4433.2s]: farming that looks more like ecosystems rather than factory production systems. To me, those,

[4433.2s - 4438.9s]: I think those are three things I've mentioned, three major shifts that I would like to see. And I

[4438.9s - 4443.6s]: think if just that happened, I mean, those are big things. But if those three things happened,

[4443.6s - 4449.3s]: we would be in a completely different place in terms of ecological health and in terms of our own

[4449.3s - 4458.9s]: health. And so those would be my magic one steps. I absolutely love it. And I love too that not only

[4458.9s - 4466.9s]: is this a big aspirational vision, but and so many folks like you and your husband, like

[4466.9s - 4473.4s]: my friends here at Elk Run Farm and many others worldwide are moving in this direction.

[4474.2s - 4482.6s]: And it's so beautiful that we have the opportunity as humans to make these kinds of choices.

[4482.8s - 4487.3s]: And may we mobilize more and more in this direction together?

[4487.3s - 4488.1s]: Yes.

[4489.4s - 4494.7s]: And that golet, thank you so much for joining us on the podcast today. It's absolutely wonderful

[4494.7s - 4501.1s]: to have this time to visit with you. Thank you for having me. See you. Bye.

segments.text: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry. And today, we're visiting with Nicolette Han Niamen, the author of Defending Beef. Nicolette, hey, how you doing? It's so great to see you today.
Thank you. I'm so happy to be here with you.

Nicolette Han Niamen is a writer, attorney, and livestock rancher. She authored the book Defending Beef as well as the book, Righteous Pork Chop, and has written numerous essays for the New York Times, the Wall Street Journal, and the Los Angeles Times.
She has also written for the Atlantic, the San Francisco Chronicle, and the Earth Island Journal.
Nicolette is a frequent speaker at National and International conferences, and was one of just 23 speakers from around the world at the Nobel Week Dialogue in 2016 in Stockholm, Sweden.
She has appeared on the PBS News Hour, the Dr. Oz Show, and in numerous films and documentaries, including eating animals, as well as sustainable.
And her work has been featured in Time, O Magazine, and the Guardian, among many others.

Previously, she was senior attorney for the Environmental Organization Waterkeeper, where she focused on animal agriculture, and before that was an Environmental Lawyer for National Wildlife Federation.

Nicolette served two terms on the City Commission for Kalamazoo, Michigan, and today, she lives in Northern California, with her two sons and her husband, Bill Niamen, founder of the Natural Meat Companies, Niamen Ranch and BN Ranch.

Nicolette, today, we're talking about defending beef, and I'm really, really excited to get into this topic, because among the many themes and threads out there in the climate movement, the regenerative movement, the food and health movement, this issue seems to be one that bubbles up quite often, and has a lot of misperceptions and varying views and opinions out there in the public.
So maybe to kick things off, I'll just throw it right up for you. Maybe it's a bit of a softball. Why does beef need defending?
Yes, well, I kind of wish that it didn't, because it's a kind of a frustrating process to have to try to defend something over and over again that you kind of don't feel needs to be defended.

But I guess it's kind of a two-pronged response. On the one hand, there's this whole question of the healthfulness of the food. Is it something that is good for our bodies and will sustain our health over the longer term?
And that's an idea that's kind of been out there. I would say since around mid-20th century, there was this kind of rise in heart disease in the industrialized world.
And there were actually two major camps on the topic. One really felt that it related to the consumption of animal fats in the industrialized world.

And then there was another group of researchers, scientists and physicians that felt that actually the shift towards more sugar in the industrialized diet was much more important in terms of what might be triggering the rise in heart disease and other diet related diseases.
And unfortunately, the sort of the dietary fat argument kind of won the day at the time.

And even though over the last couple of decades, there has been some really good and credible re-evaluation of the thought process and the research to the point where I would say the argument has actually been dismantled.
But it was out there for so many decades that it's still a very mainstream belief, even among nutritionists, dieticians and doctors.
But from my perspective, the science is basically has been broken down to the point where it's not credible anymore.
So on the health side, there's still this argument that we shouldn't be eating it because of primarily because of the saturated fat content.
And the other side, and this is kind of a more, is a little bit newer of an argument, there's this argument that meat is too ecologically damaging.
It's too resource intensive, it's too water intensive, and it's specifically beef. The beef is the one that usually gets the focus in this arena.
And then in the last decade, in particular, this idea that it's too harmful to the climate, especially because of methane.

So as a person who was kind of a lifelong environmentalist and spent three years specifically working as a lawyer for environmental organizations, nonprofit organizations, and two of those years were specifically focused on the meat industry, I'm someone who really has kind of delved into this from on a professional level.

This, you know, what what does the science really say on the ecology? And then for the last 20 years, I've been living and working on a ranch and I have met ranchers all over the world and really studied it from that perspective, from a practitioner's perspective.
And so I have increasingly become convinced that the ecological argument is just just very, very wrong on many levels.

And so what my defense of beef is is kind of this too, too pronged, you know, reputation of these two sort of, you know, I'd say almost commonly held beliefs that that beef is not good for your health and that beef is damaging to the environment.

And so I, you know, the more the more I learned about it, the more I felt that someone who had a kind of a not just a deep understanding, but a kind of a nuance understanding because of these various different components to my background.
And someone needed to really make a cohesive argument that beef was valuable food for our health and also ecologically when done well beneficial.
Yeah.
You know, I'm really, really excited. We have the opportunity to dive into this with you and unpack this a little bit for our audience.
And I have found, you know, in the years I've been doing this kind of related work that this this beef and animal issues seems to be among the most polarizing out there.

At least in the portion of our national demographic that finds the anthropomorphic climate change concerned to be genuine and what's amazing to me and what many Americans aren't aware of is that globally virtually everybody seems to be in an agreement and understanding that human impacted climate change.
And so, you know, I think that this is very real, even though here in the United States, there seems to be some confusion about this.

But within the arena of folks who are taking that threat seriously, this seems to be one of the most polarizing divisive issues, which is astonishing for those of us who are engaged directly in agriculture and especially regenerative agriculture.

And, you know, we collaborate with dozens and dozens of farmers and ranchers at many scales and not one yet in all of these years have I come across a farmer of rancher who says, yeah, we can maintain and steward soil and landscapes and ecosystems and food production without animals.
And particularly the bovine, and animals.

So, I'm hoping and in your book is so well documented, I'm going to show it to our audience that are looking at the video version of this here. And of course, audio, you're not seeing this, but it's such a beautiful book published by our friends at Chelsea Green Publishing.

And the book is so well documented. And I'm hoping that you can paint a picture for us of the scene, if you will, of cattle grazing on grasslands, the soil ecology, the water, the wildlife, the biodiversity.
Because I think a lot of folks have a very different picture in mind when thinking about this issue.

Well, first of all, you said so much, and I just want to respond quickly to a couple of points you made. First of all, I have traveled around the world quite a bit in various contexts and talking a lot of times and talking about beef and and and other, you know, capacities where I'm traveling.
And I'm always really struck by how the farming and ranching community in other parts of the world is not arguing that climate change is not happening.
So, it's still a uniquely American phenomenon pretty much that that is still a pretty widely held view in certain quarters of the agricultural community.
Although I do think that's shifting. I have noticed a dramatic difference from five or 10 years ago that there's more and more acceptance of it.

And also, interest in the idea of, okay, what can agriculture do? How can we be proactively preparing for these changes? And also, how can we be making our own practices better so that we're not contributing to the problem?

So, I think that's kind of how I see where that situation is. And then with respect to this whole question of the role of animals, I mean, I, you know, I was explaining this issue and thinking about it and writing about it for a long time before I ever heard something that Alan Savory said, the wildlife ecologist from Zimbabwe, who has done such an amazing job.
He's been managing sort of holistic management principles in grazing and agriculture in many parts of the world. And the way he said it that just made some so much sense to me.
And I think it's such a beautiful sort of encapsulation of the whole book that I wrote defending beef. And that is that essentially the globe evolved for millions of years.
And for those, for millions and millions of years, there were very large herds of grazing animals. And that that was a very important element of the Earth's ecology.
And that only in fairly recent times, you know, so like about the last 100,000 years, which is a long time. But it's very short in geological time.

Many of those animals either disappeared entirely or their populations dwindled dramatically. So we have today, just kind of a remnant of the wild grazing herds, whether they were, you know, prehistoric animals or things like caribou, which are still on the Earth, but are in much smaller numbers now.
And you can just look at it when I give talks and I, you know, show slides of the sort of the remem remnants of large grazing herds that are still on the Earth.
Caribou being one of them. And we also have things like Kate Buffalo and Will de Beast and the bison in the American West, although they're a tiny fraction of what they want to work.

But what I, what I like about showing them to people, the visualization is so important. You can see that there are large number of numbers of animals. And they're very densely congregated as they move across the landscape and they do move.
And so what what Alan Savory said a few years ago, and I've met him many times and I, I have a strong connection with them and have read his, you know, seminal book about holistic management.
